name: Persistent Delay in Paying Rent
short_description: Tenant persistently delays rent even if no arrears

whether_arrears.note: Can be used even if rent fully paid eventually
whether_arrears.key: Pattern of lateness is the issue, not amount owed

evidence_required: Detailed rent account showing payment dates
Tenancy agreement showing when rent due
Pattern of late payments over several months

high_probability: Clear pattern of late payments (e.g., 6+ months)
Rent consistently paid late by weeks
medium_probability: Some months paid on time, others late
Tenant has explanations but pattern continues
Recently improved but past pattern significant
low_probability: Genuine reasons for delays (e.g., pay date mismatch)

red_flags: Housing Benefit payment schedule causes delays
tenant_defenses: Tenant now paying by standing order to prevent delays
notes: Ground 11 is DISCRETIONARY and rarely used alone. Useful where tenant eventually pays but always late. Court considers pattern, reasons, warnings, prejudice, and reasonableness. Often combined with Grounds 8 or 10 if arrears also exist.
case_law: Holloway v Povey [1984] - Must show persistent pattern, not isolated instances
Bird v Hildage [1948] - Court considers reasonableness of granting possession
Hayman v Rowlands [1957] - Tenant's reasons for delays relevant
court_considerations: How persistent is the pattern? (How many months?)
Is it reasonable to grant possession?
Could issue be resolved by standing order/direct debit?

before_notice: Document all late payments with dates
Offer to set up standing order/direct debit
landlord_actions.importance: Courts expect landlord to raise issue before serving notice

payment_patterns.strong_case: Rent due 1st of month, paid 20th-25th for past 8 months despite warnings
payment_patterns.moderate_case: Rent paid 7-10 days late for 5 of past 8 months
payment_patterns.weak_case: Rent paid 2-3 days late occasionally, now paying on time
